columns.text: In this question, we will identify in either manner Porsche decides to enter a new market.

This quick rundown of Porsche's conviction does not include all factual information but instead raises questions for someone like you to consider. 

For example, one corporate might have had a favorable position since it can effectively extract at a relatively low upfront cost or competitive landscape. After all, another of the two might have made.
In this problem, we will discuss the possible reason why Porsche decided to enter the SUV market using the concepts we learned in this chapter.

Being the first to enter a market can be both risky and rewarding. It is risky since there is no basis as to how the market really performs but it can be rewarding since you get all of the profit at the start since you still don't have competitors. 

This is why the decision on whether to enter a market or not is crucial. More importantly, if the company does decide to enter, the timing should also be considered.

In the case of Porsche, it is possible that they were still studying the performance of the SUV market that's why they opted not to be the first to enter. It took them a long time before entering which signifies that they assessed the SUV market as a field that still has a lot of upside potential both in terms of innovation and since there are a lot of companies that passed up on the opportunity to enter the market.

The principle in this move is that as long as the market is not saturated yet, then there is always room for profit. Porsche entered the SUV market because they studied the possible upside potential of the market while it is not yet saturated.
